title: karren brady cbb dan osborne
story: The “theme” of this year’s CBB is that all the celebrities in the house have been embroiled in a scandal of some sort.But I would argue “scandal” is not quite the right word for the events that led to Osborne losing his role on Towie.In November 2014, Osborne was questioned over assault allegations after a fight with his ex, Megan Tomlin, although he was released without charge.A few months later, an audio recording emerged — allegedly secretly taken by Megan in November 2014 at her home — of Osborne apparently making foul-mouthed threats to “knife” Megan if she met another man, and referring to her as his “property”.That was three years ago, in 2015, and he went on to issue a public apology.He lost his job on Towie and also some lucrative endorsements which, no doubt, led to some soul-searching on his part.When talking about the “scandal” before entering the CBB house he said: “I said something that I never ever meant, I’m embarrassed by it. It was a horrible time.”In light of his apology, some people might talk about rehabilitation. He’s said he’s sorry and he won’t do it again.People have to be given a ­second chance — right?Before I answer that, let me flag up a few other stories that caught my eye this week.There’s the tale of Sean Simmons, 28, a domestic abuser from Hull who waterboarded one of his ex-partners, tying her to a bath before covering her face with a towel and pouring cold water over her, saying: “This is what I do to people who lie. I’m going to make you tell the truth.”Later, he produced a knife and said he’d “have to kill her”.And Darren McKie, a 43-year-old police inspector who was jailed for life after strangling his wife Leanne, 39, at their home in Cheshire, then dumping her body in a lake.And Glyn Leedell, 39, who threatened to kill a woman with a kitchen knife within hours of meeting her in a Rotherham pub.Oh, and the news that Ian Stewart, 57, who was jailed for 34 years after smothering his wife, children’s author Helen Bailey, is being questioned over the death of his first wife, Diane Stewart, who died after collapsing in the garden of the couple’s home in Cambridgeshire.I could go on, but it’s too depressing.If you read the same stories you may have taken a moment to despair that the papers are full of similar stories every day — of women being killed, brutalised and attacked by the men who purport to love them.Or, you may have barely noticed because these stories are so ­commonplace.Of course, not all men who threaten to kill their partners go on to do so.But you can be sure that most of the women above had probably suffered years of traumatic intimidation and abuse before their partners actually acted on their threats.Meanwhile, those women were ­living in fear — that’s what these chumps get off on. They want to make their victim feel helpless and powerless.So, let’s talk about forgiveness and rehabilitation.Do I think people who really regret being a perpetrator of domestic violence deserve a second chance? Yes, I do.If someone is genuinely ­repentant about anything they’ve done wrong, you can’t refuse ­forgiveness forever.Do I think that Dan Osborne’s second chance should take the form of a public platform on which to rehabilitate his image and, no doubt, earn a pretty penny or two into the bargain?No, I really, really do not.Sure, it was three years ago and no, he didn’t actually go on to act on his threat to knife his ex.But by letting him into the CBB house, Channel Five are sending a strong message that domestic violence allegations are a trivial affair, not to be taken seriously.By welcoming him in, despite his “scandal”, they are normalising and turning a blind eye to the kind of behaviour that too often ruins — and sometimes ends — women’s lives.People on TV are role models. And to allow a man who has made verbal threats to kill his girlfriend to become a role model is irresponsible in the extreme.ITV recognised this when they decided to boot him off Towie.Channel Five should have done the same.SHIRLEY BALLAS has revealed she weighs herself every day in the run up to Strictly in order to get “telly ready”.You might think that sounds extreme but, believe me, the only way to get telly ready is to take very seriously the old adage that the screen adds a stone.I don’t exactly weigh myself before filming The Apprentice or Give It A Year but, in the three months leading up to filming, I always manage to lose – by hook or by crook – a stone.In fact we all do – Lord Sugar and Claude Littner are watching what they eat as well.Then, as soon as filming stops, we all immediately put the weight back on again as normal life resumes.And, let me tell you, it’s a lot harder to take it off than it is to put it on.I’M a big believer in benefits being available to people who need help because they can’t help themselves.But the story of Bangladeshi immigrant Abdul Jalil, a father of six who came to the UK in 1969, really makes a mockery of the system.Jalil, who is 64, hasn’t worked since 1988 for “health reasons”.But a probation officer found the only problem he had is a slightly tender right knee.In 2008, he exceeded the amount of cash that claimants are allowed to have when he was loaned £25,000 to buy his council house.He did not notify the Department for Work and Pensions and continued wrongly claiming more than £28,000 over the next eight years.He then lied to the DWP about his assets as he filled out his benefits review form in 2012.He had re-mortgaged his council flat in May that year for roughly £148,000 and given the money to his children so they could purchase their own properties keeping around £86,500 for himself.Then at court this week he was spared jail – in favour of community service and even had the cheek to say he would do it if it was “light work”.I know that some people need benefits to get back on their feet, and I’m proud to live in a country that provides that.But once a person is back up, they need to actually stand on their own two feet – rather than abusing the system that helped them.Like all benefit cheats, he should pay the money back or go to jail and never be allowed access to benefits again.AS taxpayers we give almost £14BILLION a year away in foreign aid of which almost £1billion goes to the EU, and this week the Government was threatening to withdraw our cash if there was no-deal Brexit.Why wait until Brexit? Just stop it now.We need this money to fix our own country – our NHS, our police forces, our schools, benefits and housing all need it desperately.And the worst part of all this is that we have to borrow the money to give it away.Our country has almost £2TRILLION of debt, which costs around £50billion a year to service in interest.Borrowing money to give it away, it’s the economics of the madhouse.I KNOW our prisons are full, but it beggars belief that Allan Williamson, 45, was let off with a two-year community order and 30 days rehabilitation.When police raided his flat in Hulme, Manchester, they found more than 600 images – including 68 films classed as Category A, the highest level of children being sexually abused.To be clear, the images showed children as young as seven being sexually abused by adults.Still, Judge Elizabeth Nicholls,  decided prison wasn’t necessary, saying Williamson had been “open and frank” with the police about his behaviour and because the man has allegedly taken “tentative steps to address these issues”.So the guy was in possession of 600 images including many of the worst kind of paedophilia – and he’s still in the community?Who in their right mind would want this guy in their community?I know the prisons are buckling, so let’s just build more – even if that includes sending prisoners out to sea in containers.When is the justice system going to start thinking about the victims as opposed to the perpetrators?I BET the boyfriend of Kay Longstaff – the air hostess who spent ten hours in the water after plunging from a cruise liner – is feeling a bit embarrassed.Longstaff was miraculously rescued ten hours after falling – or jumping – from the Norwegian Star, 60 miles off the Croatian coast last week.It’s not quite clear what happened beforehand but other passengers and crew claim to have seen Ms Longstaff in several arguments with her partner Craig Rayment, above with Kay, on the evening of the incident.Once she’d been rescued, Mr Rayment’s estranged wife Kelly offered Ms Longstaff some unsolicited support, saying: “If I was on a ship with him, I would get off any way I could.”Oh dear.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: politicians dont answer questions
story: I have made my peace with this and accepted, regardless of the fact I have never fiddled my expenses or taken cash for ­questions, some of those who come before me have damned all politicians to the sin-bin.I do, however, think there is one very simple thing all politicians could agree to do that would help rehabilitate us to the public.We could answer a straight question with a straight answer.This week doing the rounds on Twitter was a clip of Jeremy Corbyn on Channel 4 News being asked six times: “Do you honestly believe Britain will be better off outside of the EU?”Each time he answered with a iation of, “Labour wants to maintain good relations with the EU to protect jobs”.His words are not bad — it is certainly the answer he and his team would have practised.But it is not an answer to that question and that’s the problem.To the average punter it just looks like politicians can’t be straight.The answer, as far as I’m concerned, is a big fat no.Gavin Williamson, the Defence Secretary, suffered a similar cringeworthy encounter with Richard Madeley in May.The question in the wake of the Salisbury poisonings was: “You told Russia to ‘shut up and go away’.Do you regret that now?Do you think it was too informal?”He started by answering an entirely different question about paying tribute to healthcare workers, which had absolutely nothing to do with what he was being asked.God only knows why he didn’t just say: “Yeah, it wasn’t my finest hour but I guess I was just really cross that people in Britain were being poisoned.”He could then have gone on to say all the nice things about Salisbury health workers.Instead, Madeley savaged him and all that anyone remembers of the encounter is that Gavin Williamson should avoid interviews.Mind you, at least both Corbyn and Williamson gave an answer.At least they bothered to take part.Boris Johnson would just have offered his questioner a cup of tea as if he was Mrs Doyle from Father Ted.I honestly despair.I’m not sure when the art of just repeating the same message over and over again, even if it in no way answers the question, started.Most people put it down to the Tony Blair years of slick media management, but times have surely got to move on.Politicians spend too much time hedging their bets, trying to keep all the people happy and end up pleasing no one by waffling through an answer that is basically six of one and half a dozen of the other.I get that it is hard when your job is basically a massive popularity contest, but I am not sure we are made more popular by dodging questions and refusing to give our own opinions.People contact me every single week telling me they don’t always agree with me but they appreciate that I stand up for what I believe.I honestly don’t think the British people want politicians to say an approximation of a safe answer, or to try to be pals with everyone.People have a damn sight more respect for people when they say what they think, even if they disagree.For too long politicians have been especially scared of upsetting working-class people, without recognising that most people don’t even think of themselves that way any more.I have absolutely no idea where the idea came from that the average member of the public can’t stand a bit of discussion and disagreement, or are so fragile that they will all fall apart if someone says something not to their liking.I have never once voted for someone who I agreed with 100 per cent of the time.I didn’t marry someone I agreed with a 100 per cent of the time and, frankly, if he tried to please me, placate me and pander to all my views I would no longer stay married to him, because it would be dishonest.Don’t get me wrong — saying what you think is not a universally appreciated characteristic and some do get in touch with me to tell me to shut up and go away.Much like Russia probably felt when Williamson said it to them, I pay little mind to this and crack on.Journalists do sometimes ask stupid questions.Politicians do have to be careful about what they say as it can sometimes get twisted and misrepresented.Things are not always simple, and giving a quick answer on a complex issue takes some skill.All that said, it has got to be time to stop the waffle and give the public a break from shouting at their telly each night: “For God’s sake, answer the bleedin’ question!”IT’S that time of year where slow news weeks turn to how much wine we should drink and if swearing at work should be banned.Apparently no amount of alcohol is safe, which will change absolutely no one’s behaviour, and swearing at work is bad for morale.I cannot agree on the swearing front.I am not advocating we all run around barking sweary orders and aggressive expletives at our colleagues but I find sometimes, especially in times of high stress in the office, nothing will quite explain it like a collective FFS.I have seen how a bit of good old Anglo Saxon can be used to break down barriers between me and my constituents.It stops me seeming like some lofty bureaucrat who cannot understand their problems.In some cases it makes them physically relax if we get a bit sweary about their crappy landlord or their benefits being stopped.We all swear, and most of us drink, I doubt that’s going to change.PADDY DOHERTY of My Big Fat Gypsy Wedding and Celeb Big Brother fame was in the papers this week, leading the funeral procession for his nephew.A sad affair, of course, but the diamond-encrusted funeral casket is reported to have cost £100,000.I remember organising my own mother’s funeral and balking at spending around £2,500 for an event I’d rather have not had to attend.I could hear her voice in my head saying, “How much?” as we wrote out cheques for cars and coffins. My wedding only cost £3k and I thought that was a bit much.When my time comes, I implore my family to keep their cash. I wouldn’t be thankful for money being literally burnt.THIS week’s, in fact this year’s, feminist icon goes to the unlikely Stormy Daniels.There is, of course, no reason why feminism would not extend to women performing in pornography but there are few crossovers.Stormy Daniels is a hero.World leaders across the globe pander to Trump, few are brave enough to publicly call out his racism, sexism and terrible decision making.Our own PM holds his hand, allowing him to make her look weak and feeble.Ms Daniels has been brave enough not only to take on the most powerful man in the world but also some pretty tooled-up lawyers too.After apparently receiving payment and signing a non-disclosure agreement to hush her up about an affair she had with Trump in 2006, she broke rank.This was not just a kiss and tell, this was a story that has caused Donald Trump’s lawyer Michael Cohen to plead guilty to breaking election campaign rules.He explicitly stated that he was told to pay her the money by “the candidate” meaning Trump. Donald Trump will probably get away with this misdemeanour, but it is the closest he has come to being in real trouble.Without Stormy Daniels and her courage to face down legal threats, vicious hate mail and a campaign to discredit her, powerful men would continue to use women as playthings and just pay them off when they are done.Stormy Daniels is every woman who has been messed about and we salute her for fighting back.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: just ignore bogus chancellor hammond the sun is brexing out
story: Of course, she was right to ask.Not a single public authority predicted the biggest crash in modern history — not the Bank of England, not the ­Treasury, and certainly not the Chancellor of the Exchequer.Then in 2016 they did it again. Project Fear forecast dramatic downturns in the economy if the people were so unwise as to vote for Brexit. Wrong again.Since then, we have had record levels of employment, huge investments from the likes of Google, Microsoft, SoftBank and a long list of other companies.They demonstrated their confidence in the future of this great country in the best way possible — with their money.This time round the wise insight came from Andy Haldane, the best economist at the Bank of England.Ruefully he said “economic forecasting is having a Michael Fish moment”.Michael Fish was the weather forecaster who completely mispredicted the huge 1987 storm that struck Britain.If only economic forecasters were even as good as weather forecasters, we would be a lot better off. But they are not, and they are at it again.This week Chancellor Philip Hammond predicted the Treasury would need to raise an extra £80billion in 15 years’ time in the event of a no-deal Brexit.And yet the Chancellor insists on ­trotting out yet another bogus forecast, on the very day that my successor as Brexit Secretary, Dominic Raab, is ­presenting the first set of preparation for no deal.Coincidence? I do not think so.The great departments of state are very careful about what they put in the public domain, and exactly when.For nobody is this more true than the Treasury, which has to judge the public perception of everything it does, if only because of its effect on the markets. So this was either spectacularly incompetent, or deliberate. I know what I think.And even more disgraceful, by doing so it will undermine the Government’s hand in striking a deal with the EU.If they do not think we dare walk away, then they will give us the worst deal they can think of. Bear in mind that the Chequers deal already concedes enormous amounts to the EU.It would not be long before our world-leading position in life sciences, gene technology, artificial intelligence, self-driving cars and a whole range of other modern industries would be being actively undermined by the Europeans.As for being out of reach of the ­European Court, pull the other one.But now the Treasury is beginning to fear that even these spectacular concessions the Government has made in the Chequers deal will not deliver agreement from the European Commission — or if it does, the Commons will turn it down.In that event you can expect attempts by the Remainers in Parliament to try to scupper our departure by delaying it beyond the General Election, or offer some other enormous raft of concessions to give back control of the EU.Hence the ridiculous suggestion that the Army would be used to move food around the country.Why? What conceivable aspect of European policy would handicap British hauliers moving British products from Kent to Cumbria?None of course, but it was just the bogus nonsense some of our Remainer media is only too happy to carry ­completely uncritically. Similarly, we have heard suggestions of all sorts of shortages, based it seems mostly on the idea that the French might impede the flow of goods between Calais and Dover.It would not be the first time we had dealt with such issues. We had about 30 days of such delays in 2015. I remember queues of lorries, but I do not remember shortages of food or medicines.And on other issues, are the Europeans really going to pick a fight on data with the biggest IT power on the continent, on banking are they going to refuse to cooperate with the greatest financial ­centre in the world?Are the Greeks, Italians and Spaniards going to disadvantage the UK residents on whom many of their local economies depend? Or stop tourism? I think not.I suspect we are quite likely to have the odd hiccup when we leave the EU, but we will be able to cope, which is what Dominic Raab was demonstrating this week. And any problems we have will be over in months not years.So in 15 years’ time, far from worrying about Mr Hammond’s £80billion bill, the country will have trouble remembering what all the fuss was about.The biggest question will be whether we have made the most of the opportunities created by Brexit.And that is what we should worry about today, creating the circumstances where this great country can take its proper place in the world. We will only be able to do that if we allow ourselves the freedoms a clean Brexit will deliver.So my advice to all my old colleagues in Cabinet is simple: Ignore the misery merchants of the Treasury, stop fearing things that will never happen, and start planning for the real opportunities that this great country can grasp when it sets its mind to it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu diplomats no flights no ships brexit
story: Senior diplomats told The Sun that Brits would face “no flights to and from the UK, no ships, no economic activity and no financial transactions” if we failed to agree a deal before we leave the bloc next March.One ambassador predicted the chaos for businesses and ordinary people in the UK would get so bad the situation would quickly become untenable for the Government.And a senior EU official said Brussels negotiators were banking on it being such a disaster that the “cycle of negotiations and the political dynamics will be taken over by the real world”. But leading Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg dismissed the “delusional”.He hit back at Brussels, telling The Sun: “It is wishful thinking by a EU establishment that has failed to notice that its grand scheme has failed economically, is devoid of democratic support and is increasing unpopular across the continent.EU sources also questioned Brexit secretary Dominic Raab’s upbeat assessment of how the UK would cope in the first few weeks of a no deal outcome. One said they “wouldn’t count on” his reassurance that Brits will still be able to enjoy a BLT sandwich in such a scenario.Last week the Government published a slew of notices warning people and businesses how to prepare for a crash out situation in March next year.Announcing them, Mr Raab dismissed suggestions the army and Air Force would have to be deployed to secure food and medicine supplies as “scare stories”. And in a bizarre pledge, he said Brits will “still be able to enjoy a BLT after Brexit”.But asked whether the UK Government could survive the first few days of a no deal exit, an EU ambassador told The Sun: “It’s not possible to have a no deal. There would be a massive outcry.“With even a no deal for one week, with no flights to and from the UK, no ships, imagine the economic loss of one week of no economic activity, no personal activity, no financial transactions. That would already be a disaster.”The diplomat added that Britain’s sluggish economic growth over the past year meant it was already “falling behind more and more” compared to the rest of the continent.The EU Commission has slashed its growth forecast for the UK to just 1.3 per cent for 2018, the joint lowest rate alongside struggling Italy.And EU officials believe that business pressure on Ministers to reach a compromise and avoid a crash out will crescendo in the next few months.A senior EU official told The Sun: “The moment the markets understand this is going in the wrong way, the cycle of negotiations and the political dynamics will be taken over by the real world.“In a few months the UK will have a credibility issue. The moment economic operators understand this is going wrong there will be events on the ground.”Meanwhile a former EU chief sparked outrage yesterday by claiming a no deal Brexit would trigger the break-up of the UK.Former European Council President Herman Van Rompuy said: “We could end up with a situation in which the EU27 becomes more united and a United Kingdom less united. This talk about a ‘no deal’ is the kind of nationalist rhetoric that belongs to another era.”THE Eurocrats are losing the plot.We’re used to their regular predictions that Britain will turn into the 10th circle of hell once we leave the EU. But even we’re taken aback by the ridiculous warning that we’ll have “no economic activity” the day after a clean break Brexit.These bizarre forecasts show the arrogance of those who rise to the top of the European tree.They genuinely believe that without their flag, their bureaucracy and their anthem that the continent will just fall apart.And it reveals their motives in the Brexit negotiations. To punish us, and send a message to anybody thinking of heading for the exit door – no matter how disastrous it is for the European economy.How are we supposed to negotiate in good faith? They can barely conceal their hope that the UK is going to slip into anarchy.The Government must continue to plan for a clean break. And treat everything Brussels says with not so much a pinch but a whole bucketload of salt.Meanwhile, for all their cocksure bravado, the EU is in all sorts of trouble.Unelected bosses in Brussels are in open warfare with the elected leaders of Poland and Hungary and are now fixing for a fight with Italy, too.Even the EU’s so-called ‘triumph’ in Greece will ring hollow to the 40% of youngsters there who are still out of work.Some ardent Remainers at home are still hoping that Britain might change its mind on leaving.But Brussels keeps proving that we’re better off out. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: public sector staff penion pay gap
story: A public sector employee currently earning the national average wage of £28,600 a year will retire with a £17,563-a-year pension.But someone working in the private sector on the same salary and making the same level of pension contributions would retire with just £6,412 a year.The private sector employee would have to save £3 in every £10 of their earnings - £8,606 a year - to retire with a pension as large as the public sector worker’s pension.The Taxpayers’ Alliance, which carried out the analysis, said the massive £11,000 a year gap laid bare how unjust the current pension system is for private sector workers, who end up picking up the bill for the “unfairly-generous” public sector pensions.Public sector pensions cost the public purse £38 billion last year - more than the entire UK defence budget. But despite this, the pensions are unfunded - meaning the whole bill has to be paid out of general taxation.Government liabilities for all exisitng unfunded pension obligations was a staggering £1.7 trillion in 2017. This is nearly as much as Britain’s official national debt of £1.8 trillion.The Taxpayers’ Alliance has called on ministers to stop raiding private pension pots and start funding public sector pensions to narrow the gap.Total pay in the public sector - including the value of pension contributions and bonuses, is on average 23 per cent higher than the private sector for comparable workers.Taxpayers’ Alliance boss John O’Connell blasted: “Workers in the private sector are paying for their public sector counterparts to enjoy a retirement they can only dream of, and that disparity has been brutally compounded over the years by politicians continuously launching raids on private pensions.“What’s more, pension promises made to public sector workers are unfunded and will continue to be paid out of general taxation - that is unsustainable as people are living a lot longer than when these schemes were cooked up.“To stop kicking the can down the road, reforms must ensure that new public sector pensions are properly funded and not paid for by the taxpayers of the future, namely our children and grandchildren.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle wedding ring jewellers business boom
story: The newlywed Duchess of Sussex has helped a jeweller open four new stores - and beat the slump in the high street.Up to thirty new jobs are being created in the jewellers after the “Meg effect” sent their sales soaring.Prince Harrys bride Meghan wears a wedding ring with gold from the Clogau mine in North Wales - carrying on a 95-year-old royal tradition.The new Clogau brand stores in Wales and Merseyside also use gold mined from the same St Davids mine source.The firm is opening stores in in Llandudno, Bangor, Swansea and a new larger site for its outlet at Cheshire Oaks retail park at Ellesmere Port.They will create up to 30 new jobs and provide a boost to high streets at a time when the retail sector is struggling.A spokeswoman said: Its nice to have an association with the modern royal family and to see them carrying on the tradition.The jewellers first used rare Welsh gold from the Clogau mine in 1994 with brides-to-be among their best customers.The first royal bride to wear a Clogau ring was the Queen Mother.The company already employs more than 120 people.A spokeswoman said: “With the UK High Street facing tough trading times, Clogau’s expansion brings a much needed boost to the local economies where the new stores will be located.“Twenty to thirty new jobs will be created and the brand will engage with other local businesses to make the most of the commercial opportunities.”

title: seaside chalet on cornwalls longest sandy beach could be yours for 375k
story: Seawhispers is a quirky little property with picturesque views of Godrevy Beach - popular with surfers and walkers - the sea and the lighthouse in St Ives Bay.The chalet has previously been used as a holiday let, but could be a surfers dream home, a familys holiday getaway or a great investment for a savvy business owner.The origins of the little beach side chalets date back to the 1800s when travelling miners would live in Gypsy caravans pulled by horses and go wherever the best paid work was.They gathered in set areas, like the dunes at Gwithian Towans, and eventually settled and built more permanent homes.Seawhispers has a lobby, open-plan living/dining room and semi open-plan kitchen and two double bedrooms with en suite bathrooms.It has been thoroughly modernised throughout and is one of the few chalets that is not on the front row but still has spectacular views of the beach and lighthouse.The white, octagonal 85ft Godrevy lighthouse, built in 1858, was made famous by Virginia Woolfe in her novel To The Lighthouse.It sits on an island three miles out to sea from the bay, which is now a haven for seabirds.Seawhispers is in a secluded cul-de-sac, less than a two-minute walk from the beach. It also has a small garden with lawn and decking and even a white picket fence.Guy Morse from Lillicrap Chilcott, who are selling the property, said: Its such an amazing place to be, right down by the beach. It has a very much oldie-worldy style.The beach is one of the best surf beaches in Cornwall and its also the longest beach in the county so these chalets have a real draw because of that.Theres a nice little community there, although its mostly driven by the holiday season, and Gwithian is one of the prettiest villages, it is set down behind the sand dunes and there are lots of lovely little cottages.A lot of the chalets only have glimpses of a view, unless theyre on the frontline and then you pay a premium.But this one happens to be well positioned as, although its not in the front row, it looks down the access lane and you can see the lighthouse, which is the thing people want to see. The prices have risen quite a lot in recent years, theres a limited number and theres always people waiting to buy them.Theres no reason why it cant be a permanent home, its being sold without any residential restrictions, but we expect most people will consider buying as a holiday home.The current owners have done a lot of work to it - plumbing, electrics, new kitchen, roof - so its in top order now.It also has a small garden, although really the sand dunes are your garden. Its protected land but with public access so its an amazing place to go dog walking or for children to play and its something you wouldnt find anywhere else in the county.That all sort of adds to the magic of it.

title: ufo landing pad argentinian desert
story: Swiss man Werner Jaisli claims he was contacted by extra terrestrials who told him they needed a landing spot on Earth.The spectacular space terminal is a collection of rocks which form the shape of a star - known as an ovniport - near the small town of Cachi in the province of Salta.Jaisli is reported to have claimed to have constructed the site after he received a telepathic message from aliens telling him they needed a site to land on earth.He told Argentine newspaper El Tribuno: They landed about 100 metres above our heads and projected on us a beam of light that made us both see their own brightness.The funny thing is that it did not affect our vision. Something began to bubble through my brain: it was an order. They asked me telepathically to build the airport.Jasli is then said to have constructed a large star in 2008 with 36 points that measures 48 metres in diameter. He then added a smaller star later.Not surprisingly, the site is a huge attraction for UFO nuts who hope to contact ETs who have travelled light years from darkest space.To add to the mystery, soon after the site was completed locals say they stopped seeing Jaisli- sparking theories he had been abducted by aliens. However, it is thought he actually travelled back to Switzerland.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: women wrestle gravy world championship lancashire
story: Lads and lasses have entered the saucy affair which takes place every year.This is the eleventh time the event has been held and the county has been a veritable hot pot of anticipation.The saucy event sees combatants in fancy dress get down and dirty in as they try to slam each other to the ground in gravy filled paddling pools.It is held at the Rose n Bowl to raise funds for the East Lancashire Hospice amongst other charities.The local fire brigade are also on hand to hose down the wrestlers between bouts.On the events website it is described as: Without a doubt this is one of the World’s craziest culinary competitions. A wild and whacky wrestling competition in a pool full of Lancashire Gravy!Contestants must wrestle in the Gravy for 2 minutes, Points are scored for fancy dress, comedy effect, entertainment and oh! yes, wrestling ability.All our contestants get sponsorship and really give it their all to raise money for charity.There are many activities for the family, in previous years we have had cheer leading groups, BB gun shooting range, Bouncy castles, face painting, craft beer stalls, cake and tombola stands.Also kids get a chance to get a go in the gravy.Food and drink are also provided in what is billed as a great day out for all the family.Last years winners were Trevor Stirling in the mens category and Roxy Afzal was crowd queen of the ring in the womens.This year fighters have iously dressed up a Mr Incredible, Donald Trump and Fred Flinstone as they come to blows in the meaty brown gravy.

title: gran holds christening ceremony dog
story: Wearing a ping sparkly tu-tu and matching neck-bow, the animal was surrounded by adoring fans bearing gifts as she received the word of God.Owner Elaine Lyons became attached to the three-year-old Pugalier after the sudden death of her husband, reports Wales Online.She said she initially came up with the idea to bless her pet as a bit of a joke.Fast forward a few weeks, however, and an officiator was wetting Cocopops head with blessed water from a plastic bottle in the shape of the Virgin Mary.The pet - apparently due to get hitched to another dog called Alfie - was even presented with a glittering pink cake topped with a silver tiara.There was music and dancing, with Cocopops filmed as Elaine jiggled her in her arms to Barry Manilows Copacabana.Elaine, from Merthyr Tydfil, said: “I never thought I would be like this.“My neighbours always buy her things and bother with her. They come over with dog treats and look after her, so one day I just said ‘why don’t you become Coco’s godparents?’“It started off as a bit of a joke but here we are. It happens in America, doesnt it, but it never happens in Merthyr, so I thought, why not?”At the ceremony, well-wishers applauded and later lined up to present their gifts to Coco and Elaine.The godparents, couple Debbie Smith and Emidio Franca, who live across the road, stood by like any other proud godparents at any other christening.The ceremonys acting officiant Karen Meyrick, who has been a friend of Elaine’s for around 23 years, said: “I have never done anything like this in my life – I only just found out today I’d be doing this!”Despite the obvious amount of love for Cocopops, Elaine admitted that she was previously never bothered about owning a pet.Mum-of-three Elaine, who works at Prince Charles Hospital, said: “My son’s dog had puppies and Coco was the runt of the litter. She was so little she could fit in your hand.“I said to my son, ‘Please can I have her?’ It’s been three years now.“I can’t imagine life without my Cocopops now. I absolutely love her.”Coco has been a source of comfort for Elaine in recent years following her husbands death.Elaine’s husband Colin died suddenly from a heart attack around eight years ago, aged just 46. The couple had been together for 28 years, and married for seven years.Elaine said: “He had a heart attack when he was 38, and then he died suddenly when he was 46. I was left in the house on my own and it was horrible.”Elaine presented Coco’s godparents with an engraved keyring each, marking the day.Godmother Debbie Smith, 56, said: “I fell in love with Coco when I first saw her.“We love seeing her, she came around for Christmas dinner last year. She was dressed up as Santa.”Although she’s only just been christened, a wedding is now on the cards for Coco, with Elaine planning a marriage with her neighbour’s dog Alfie in the coming months.

title: randy dolphin rubbing itself against swimmers sparks beach ban in french resort loved by brit tourists
story: The mayor of Landevennec, in Brittany, has outlawed bathing and diving from the districts beaches whenever the horny animal is spotted.The move came after after the visibly excited three-metre  dolphin - nicknamed Zafar - rubbed himself up against boats and bathers.I issued the decree to ensure safety... title: flights grounded no deal brexit
story: There is no fall-back plan for air traffic control rights under World Trade Organisation rules in the event a deal cannot be struck with Brussels, the Institute for Economic Affairs warned.But the IEA stressed there are options available to the Government to put measures in place before March - and while it would “require flexibility on both sides”, there is an “overwhelming” mutual interest in protecting aviation from upheaval.In the first of a series of “no deal fear checker” reports released on Monday, it said the risk of flights being grounded was “conceivable, but still very unlikely”.The report said leaving the EU’s Single Aviation Market  in March without a replacement arrangement would see most UK-based airlines lose their operating licences for the 27 countries.Sam currently covers the UK’s rights to the so-called “freedoms of the air”, which include overflights of countries without landing and operating internal flights in foreign countries.The UK would also lose air traffic rights to countries including the United States, Canada and Switzerland because they had been made through the EU.In the report Julian Jessop, the IEA’s chief economist, wrote: “In summary, if there are no alternative arrangements in place, it would be as bad as the worst fears suggest: planes would not be allowed to fly.”However, the report said there were options open to the Government.It could “immediately” join other non-EU countries Norway and Iceland as members of the European Common Aviation Area , although this “off the shelf” option would mean following existing EU rules and “fudging” some of the Government’s Brexit “red lines”.Or negotiate a bespoke free trade agreement for aviation which would give the UK more control over the rules but could also mean “reduced access to the EU market” and “would also take longer to agree”. Negotiations would be made more difficult if the EU takes a hard line in the event of a fractious no-deal Brexit, it adds.There are also three “reasons for optimism” that the worst-case scenario would not be realised, it found.The UK is a world leader in aviation, which means it has “plenty of leverage” as the largest market in Europe and the third largest in the world.The report also says there are strong mutual interests in a beneficial arrangement: “Grounding UK airlines would be hugely damaging for the EU economy, particularly in areas like tourism.“And, of course, foreign airlines presumably want to continue to fly to and from the UK as well.“Since these agreements are reciprocal, it is unlikely that other countries would deny the UK the most important rights when they would then almost certainly lose them too.”It continues: “Third, even if this is left to the last moment, there are several quick fixes.“In particular, the UK and EU [or a third country like the US] could agree at least a temporary extension of the current arrangements by something as simple as a memorandum of understanding.“The key question for the EU is whether the necessity of keeping planes flying outweighs any threats to the integrity of the single market or the risks of giving the UK special treatment - the answer must surely be ‘yes’.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: myanmar generals must be tried for genocide against rohingya un
story: The UN report called for the alleged crimes to be investigated by the International Criminal Court  in The Hague.However, Myanmar is not a signatory to the Rome Statute that established the court - so a referral would need Security Council approval. It is unclear whether China would agree.The report says that instead an ad hoc body could be established to conduct prosecutions.:: Rohingya babies dumped and left to die in Myanmar crisis "Military necessity would never justify killing indiscriminately, gang raping women, assaulting children, and burning entire villages," the report says."They are shocking for the level of denial, normalcy and impunity that is attached to them."The Tatmadaw's contempt for human life, integrity and freedom, and for international law generally, should be a cause of concern for the entire population."The report goes on to state that "the manner in which" the alleged crimes in Rahkine were "perpetrated, are similar in nature, gravity and scope to those that have allowed genocidal intent to be established in other contexts".,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"Myanmar's military denies the claims.The commander-in-chief of Myanmar's armed forces, called the Tatmatdaw, Senior-General Min Aung Hlaing, was among those singled out in the allegations. Five other military commanders are also named in the report.The report also accuses the head of government Aung San Suu Kyi of failing to prevent the violence.:: Satellite images 'prove Rohingya villages were burned' So far, despite numerous ongoing investigations, the ICC has convicted only three living people, none of whom for genocide.Several ethnic Serbs involved in the Balkan wars were convicted of genocide, as well as other crimes, by the Hague-based International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia, and received ious sentences.The UN report states that the "exodus" of the Rohingya was sparked when an Rohingya insurgent group called ARSA led attacks on military and security outposts across northern Rakhine State on 25 August 2017 - and the army responded with massive force.The mission said the retaliation took place in a climate that had been fostered by hate speech, providing an example from November 2012 when "a leading Rakhine political party cited Hitler, arguing that 'inhuman acts' were sometimes necessary to 'maintain a race'".While the team compiling the report was never granted access to Myanmar, their evidence came from primary sources, including 875 in-depth interviews with victims and eyewitnesses, satellite imagery, photographs and videos. Mr Hunt said he would visit Myanmar to seek answers regarding the "deeply disturbing" treatment of the Rohingya people "at the earliest opportunity"."There must be never be a hiding place for those who commit these kind of atrocities. Have decided to visit Burma to seek answers," he said.

title: peoples vote campaigners bid to change labours stance on second brexit referendum
story: Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer has said Labour support for such a move should be "on the table", while shadow chancellor John McDonnell has stated "we're not taking any options off the table".Supporters of a second referendum argue it is necessary because although the electorate in 2016 voted for a departure, they did not vote for the final destination - what Britain's relationship with Europe should be like outside the EU.Opponents say it would undermine the democratic process and accuse referendum backers of trying to re-run the 2016 vote because they do not like the outcome.The leaked memo says the cross-party group is not trying to undermine Jeremy Corbyn's leadership by seeking a change in position. It says: "Whatever views people have about the overall direction of the Labour Party, this campaign is not about Jeremy Corbyn and we must not - will not - use it to damage or undermine the party's leadership or attack them personally.",targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"The memo has been written by Tom Baldwin, director of communications for People's Vote and a former adviser to Mr Corbyn's predecessor, Ed Miliband.It praises Labour's frontbench for showing "real signs of movement" on the issue, something which should be "supported and encouraged".Mr Baldwin said: "It's vital that people recognise that this is such a huge issue for our country, for the next generation, for our vital public services, for our jobs, that it's not something that should be used for any other objective.

story: NewsopinionKevin Maguire: The former bingo caller who can make Labour clickety-clickThe Liverpool-born MP for Hayes and Harlington in West London is overseeing the party’s preparations for government, as they sense the Tories’ collapse is imminent amid an uncivil war over BrexitShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor21:32, 26 AUG 2018Updated08:05, 27 AUG 2018NewsopinionShadow Chancellor John McDonnell is reasserting his position as leader Jeremy Corbyn’s closest comrade"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour's fate is in the hands of a former bingo caller and trainee priest with a growing reputation for solving problems. Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell used to call out “Number 10, Wilson’s Den” in Great Yarmouth. He spent three teenage years in a Catholic seminary before, as he puts it, discovering women – so celibacy went bang out of the window. Now, he is reasserting his position as leader Jeremy Corbyn’s closest comrade. The Liverpool-born MP for Hayes and Harlington in West London is overseeing the party’s preparations for government, as they sense the Tories’ collapse is imminent amid an uncivil war over Brexit. “I had been saying pessimistically that the Tories would cling on to office,” he told me. “Now, I think anything can happen.” McDonnell is the architect of Labour’s alternative economic plan to boost living standards by ending Conservative austerity.  And he has lined up meetings next month with bankers Goldman Sachs and Nobel Prize-winning economist Joseph Stiglitz, as well as trade unionists Len McCluskey, Dave Prentis and Tim Roache to fine-tune Labour’s policies. The party’s plan to hike taxes for high earners and big corporations was a 2017 masterstroke that he’ll repeat in the next election manifesto. Once the fearsome “Mac the Knife”, McDonnell has recently morphed into a peacemaker. He’s demanding Labour stamps out anti-Semitism and appealing to pro-Europeans by leaving the door open to giving people a vote on Brexit. These moves were described by an ally as signs that McDonnell is clearing roadblocks to power.

title: august bank holiday last minute
story: AdvertorialAugust Bank Holiday: Last-minute ideas for a family getawayIt's your last chance to enjoy a bank holiday before ChristmasShare&nbspByDave Masters12:14, 24 AUG 2018Updated13:09, 24 AUG 2018AdvertorialFamily fun is just around the corner"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailYou're all set for the kids to go back to school and you've had an amazing summer of glorious weather and quality family time. But wait, it's not over yet, we've got one last bank holiday to go and it's really worth being prepared for it. By this point, we've all had enough of cowering from the heatwave sun so the end-of-summer cooldown is most welcome. That means it’s the ideal time to get out and enjoy some activities. Below we've pulled together some great ideas for making the most out of the last bank holiday before Christmas... Get out on a family cycling adventure  If you've been putting off taking the kids out to practise cycling, this last bank holiday is the ideal time to get out for a ride. Head out to some quiet woodland, or check out the Halfords widget below to find your nearest cycling route.   If you want to head further afield, then don't forget that it's easy enough to add a bike rack to your car.  The Thule ProRide 591 Roof Mount Bike Carrier  is &pound75  and useful because you can add more than one to a roof rack - making it perfect for growing families. Halfords also sell a wide range of roof racks - and will fit them for you too. Enjoy a camping trip to Scotland  One of the great things about Scotland - aside from the stunning countryside - is freedom to roam. It means camping is allowed on public, unenclosed, land for no more than two or three nights. Your other option is to visit one of the many existing campsites across the country, such as at Loch Lomond Ardlui, Loch Ness Borlum, or one of the many along the coast Clachtoll Beach Campsite at Sutherland.  For camping, we suggest the Halfords 4 Person Double Skin Tent  which is now just &pound40, save &pound60, and takes just 15 minutes to pitch. If you're driving with all your camping gear, you'll also want to consider boot space.  It's surprising how much stuff you need to take the kids away for a couple of nights and you don't want to be uncomfortable in the car.  For added space, grab the Exodus 470L Black Roof Box Fully Fitted Bundle  from Halfords. It's &pound389  and includes the fitting and a roof rack suitable for your car. Find the perfect spot for a picnic  Take a picnic out with you and you'll have everything you need for a great day out. You could even pack the Halfords Portable Gas Stove , which is now &pound8 . But don't forget to pick up the correct Campingaz CP250  Gas Cartridge to go with it - these are just &pound2 each or four for &pound5.  Just make sure you're allowed to cook at your destination – many beaches only allow barbeques and small stoves after most people have gone home. It's well worth checking with the local council if you're not sure. Go on a great road trip!  A day trip or staycation break by road could be perfect for your family. Avoid queues by bagging a handy sat nav - which will also keep you on route and give you a pretty reliable answer to the 'are we there yet?' question. The Garmin Drive Sat Nav  - priced &pound89.99  comes with lifetime map updates so you're never going to find yourself driving down a newly-closed street or down a disused road.  Also be sure to check your car is in good shape before heading out as there's nothing worse than planning a great bank holiday trip only to be thwarted by vehicle trouble. There are some simple things to keep an eye out for. Firstly, how is your car battery doing? Telltale signs that something is wrong include trouble starting the engine and lights that are dim when the engine isn't running - simple enough to check when you're parked up. Also, be wary that the hot summer months have a big impact on your car battery.

title: autistic man fed up being
story: NewsAutistic man fed-up of being called a liar reveals five things you should never say to someone with conditionEXCLUSIVE: Andy Burns, 26, says he faces endless battles getting people to understand his condition - with some even accusing him of lying 'because he doesn't look autistic'Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop12:47, 27 AUG 2018Updated16:23, 27 AUG 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/stop-comparing-rainman-man-reveals-13075803,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn autistic man has pleaded with strangers to 'stop comparing me to Rain Man' as he reveals five things you should never say to someone with the condition. Andy Burns, 26, has taken to YouTube with a list of misconceptions people have about his disorder, including thinking he can't understand social interactions. He says he has even been accused of lying about having the condition because he doesn't look autistic. The young man, from Newcastle, says: Myself and many other people constantly have our diagnosis' questioned based on two minute conversations. Not all autistics are like Dustin Hoffman's Raymond from Rain Man - I get this comparison often and it's not an accurate reflection of me and other autistics.  Not all autistic people have 'special abilities' like people tend to think. Autism doesn't just influence the way I communicate, but how I see, hear and experience the world around me. He adds: For example, someone who is not on the spectrum could be able to go into a supermarket with no problems. But for me, I experience everything more intensely to a point where the lights are blinding, music is pulsating and people walking close to me becomes uncomfortable. Andy, an administrator, says he was bullied as a child for having autism.  He finds it upsetting when he hears of parents who are disappointed when they are told their own child has the disorder. In a bid to raise awareness, he has detailed five things you should never say to an autistic person on his YouTube channel Indie Andy . 1. Not all autistic people look the same Andy says: Autism has many faces and appears in many different ways - and there are different severities - For myself I am considered to be high functioning. I know general social norms and can act appropriately in social environments Someone who's low functioning may not have that social etiquette. 2. Everyone is a little autistic He says: It depends what context you mean. Mainly my understanding of this phrase is the social awkwardness and missing social cues. But you have many other things that come with it like stimming, sensory issues, social communication issues. I personally don't find it offensive but I do think there's a difference between someone being socially awkward and hardly making eye contact to someone who is autistic, who has real trouble making eye contact and communicating effectively.  3. Autistic people can't feel empathy He says: A lot of us feel emotion harder than someone who doesn't have autism and from my personal experience I have trouble being able to relate to someone's situation. This is just due to lack of experience with that situation in that time. I can understand how people feel most of the time but for me, I struggle to put myself in their shoes because if I haven't been in that situation then it's hard to imagine it. I feel like people misinterpret that as not having empathy. I know when someone's feeling upset about something - the first thing I ask is: 'Are you ok?' and 'Is there anything I can do for you?'  do feel empathy but it's just not in a way that's conventional or ordinary or considered normal.  4. You must be really high functioning He says: This upsets me - just because someone appears to be coping in a situation - like being in a nightclub say where there's lots of flashing lights loud music etc - doesn't mean they don't find things difficult in other aspects. Just because you see me in a situation doesn't mean I don't have struggles of my own and it's likely I will have been in that situation many times before and that's why I seem ok. Explaining how the condition affects him, he adds: From becoming overwhelmed by small changes to feeling like no one understands me, it can be a struggle. I still struggle with unexpected change to my routine and environment today. I really thrive on familiarity and things staying the same.  But when there is change, I feel like my world is falling apart and this anxiety has led to a few autistic meltdowns in the past. Even as an adult, I still have meltdowns which involve emotional frustration, crying and just finding the smallest of tasks like competing in a marathon. BUT this is not my life 24/7. One of the worst situations for Andy are children's parties, because they tend to be very loud and messy. When he has an autistic meltdown he says anxiety sinks in and he can feel himself becoming snappy. I sometimes can't hide how I feel and it all comes out wrong, he says. My heart beats faster and it's like my heart wants to escape my chest. I find it nearly impossible to understand what people are saying to me and everything just becomes overwhelming. 5. You must be really good with maths, IT, numbers, binary code He says: This is simply not the case. There are autistics who do love maths and are good with numbers and code, however not all autistics are the same. Though we can have similarities in the way we show our symptoms, it is a very individual condition and the support that each of us may need will differ depending on the autistic in question.  Andy was diagnosed with autism aged four, but he said he didn't really become aware he had the condition until he was 10. He had started to notice he was being segregated from his classmates into a room with a group of people who had autism and learning difficulties. He says he also faced taunts from some other students over his condition, causing him to heartbreakingly ask his mum: Why am I different? He says: She explained the fact that I have autism but it makes me who I am. At first, I wasn't proud of the fact that I am on the autism spectrum. Like every kid, I just wanted to fit in at school and try to avoid the 'weirdo' label. But despite how hard I tried to fit in, most of my peers couldn't see past the label that I somehow adopted. I did have some friends who stuck up for me but most other students treated me quite terribly. There was the name calling, physical threats and general mental torture by saying that is was no good at anything etc.  All of this was pretty constant from what I can recall and even when I told teachers about it  it never stopped. I try not to think about because I was a different person back then. While Andy received a positive response from his mum about his condition, he says it upsets him to hear that some other parents are disappointed to find out their child has it. He says: Now I am not a father or a parent but being autistic does not mean that their child won't grow up to lead a reasonably normal live. I can only imagine that not knowing what your child's future will be like is a really intimidating concept. But with the right support from school, health and from family and friends, autistic people have the opportunity to live fulfilling and meaningful lives. I do think this mindset is based on a misunderstanding about autism and if you are not involved in that world is understandable. Andy says he struggled with dating when he was younger, but he is now happily settled with fiancee Nicola, whom he has been with for five years. The couple plan to marry in 2020.
