title: bridesmaid walks down aisle newborn
story: NewsBridesmaid walks down the aisle with newborn baby 12 HOURS after giving birth thanks to "super nurses"New mum Rachael Glaister, 26, only had one hour sleep when she joined sister-in-law Leanne Johnston and husband Sean for their big dayShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMark Lister18:58, 27 AUG 2018Updated19:02, 27 AUG 2018NewsRachael Glaister and husband Jason with their newborn daughter Rose "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA bridesmaid walked down the aisle with her newborn baby just 12 hours after giving birth. New mum Rachael Glaister, 26, only had one hour sleep when she joined her sister-in-law Leanne Johnston for her big day. She and husband Jason, 28, had welcomed their little girl into the world at 11.50pm last Friday - but at 12pm the next day they were celebrating with Leanne and husband Sean. And little Rose only met her grandma 15 minutes before Rachael walked down the aisle. Rachael and Jason, of Newlands Lane, Workington, Cumbria, did not know if they would have made the wedding when the first-time mum went into labour on Friday morning, a week after Rose's due date.  But they said thanks to the amazing support of the super-nurses at Whitehaven's West Cumberland Hospital they were able to make the wedding at Sella Park Hotel, Calderbridge, where they also spent their first night as parents. Rachael said: Everyone was panicking and thinking we wouldn't be there, but the staff in the delivery suite were brilliant, they got me ready and made sure the baby was okay. It meant the world for me to be there, Leanne is my sister-in-law and I wouldn't have missed her wedding for the world. Jason added: It was really emotional to see Rachael coming down the aisle holding our baby at my sister's wedding. My mum only met Rose 15 minutes before the ceremony.  We'd only had an hour sleep the night before, but we weren't tired because of the buzz. I had to rush home and get everything for Rachael to do her hair and make-up and everything for the baby and rush back to hospital so we could get ready. I didn't even know how to fold the pram, I had to look it up on YouTube. A 12-month countdown started earlier this year to decide the future of the consultant-led maternity unit at the West Cumberland Hospital. But Rachael and Jason said had it not been for the amazing support of staff at the hospital's maternity unity, they would have missed out on their special family day, celebrating both Leanne's wedding and the birth of Rose.

title: chip shop good customers flying
story: NewsChip shop is so good it has customers flying in by plane and queues can stretch for over an hourBatter made with real dripping has drawn customers to Upton Fish Shop in Gainsborough, north Lincs from miles aroundShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLucy ThorntonDaniel Sheridan17:12, 27 AUG 2018Updated17:37, 27 AUG 2018NewsJanet Gillespie is bringing in customers from far and wide "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA chip shop has become so popular customers have been flying in by private plane . Upton Fish Shop has become one of Britain's most popular chip shops despite only opening six hours a week. Even the hour-long queues fail to put customers off. Owner Sally Shaw, 45, uses a 66-year-old batter recipe which attracts customers from miles around. The fish and chips are cooked in dripping in a huge coal-fired range - believed to be one of only two in operation in the UK.  People queue down the street in Gainsborough, north Lincs., when it opens on Friday nights and Saturday lunchtimes - and some even bring camp chairs to sit on. The takeaway, which recently celebrated its 70th anniversary, has had customers to fly into a nearby airstrip on private planes from across the country. It's popular with staff too, as one devoted staff member has worked there for 52 years. Sally, who purchased the takeaway at auction in 2005, said she can't believe the popularity of the 70 sq ft shop.  She said: People will queue all of the way down the street. I never get to see how many people are outside from behind the counter but customers will get to the front and say 'we have been in the queue for over an hour tonight'. It is a regular thing, if someone tells me they have been queuing for half an hour I cheekily tell them that doesn't sound too bad.  Long-serving member of staff, Janet Gillespie, 74, jokes she's probably past her sell-by date by now, adding: I have enjoyed every single minute of it. The customers are all fantastic, they are like friends to me. I have never heard a bad word or complaint said about the shop, we treat everybody exactly the same whether they have been coming forever or it is their first time.   Is this Britain's most expensive pint? Hipster pub selling beer for 5 TIMES the price because of its very odd ingredients  Janet started work at the shop after making a pledge when she was eight years old to the previous owner. She explained: I told Mrs Longden, 'I want to work behind the counter here one day'. It is the best decision I ever made. I have such a passion for it. I will carry on working here until I get thrown out, I will never leave.  My family joke if I'm not at the chip shop on a Friday night, I'm probably dead. The limit operating hours were used by the previous owner and Sally continued with them to keep everything the same. Sally said: I have known people come from Leicester, from North Yorkshire, from all over the place, she explained.  Some customers come every week without fail and many have been coming for decades. Customers have become so used to having to wait for their favourite meal they have created a system to work out how long they have left to wait.  Sally explained: The customers can work out how far away from the food they are by different points on the street. At one post they know they are an hour away, at another they know they are half an hour away.  It has become a bit of a social event, people bring their camping chairs and sit and have a chat while waiting.

title: dying man 31 went stag
story: NewsDying man, 31, went on 'stag do' with his mates even though he wasn't getting marriedAndy Godden, from Toxeth, Liverpool, passed away earlier this year after suffering from bowel cancer for two yearsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie McCoidElaine McCahill12:29, 27 AUG 2018Updated13:54, 27 AUG 2018NewsAndy, 31, went on a stag do with his mates even though he wasn't getting married "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who was dying went on a 'stag do' with his mates even though he wasn't getting married. Andy Godden, from Liverpool, passed away earlier this year aged 32 after suffering from bowel cancer for two years. His friends are now running the Great North Run in his honour and told of how their pal was determined to live life to the full despite his illness.  His friend Tom Loughlin, 31, help to organise the stag and told the Liverpool Echo: Andy and his partner Jess had spoken about getting married, but decided against it in the end - but he still wanted the experience of the stag.   Over the past five years a lot of our group of friends have had weddings, with us all going on about seven stag dos as a group. Despite not getting married Andy decided he'd love to have a stag, so we planned a weekend in Manchester, with all his blokey mates. We stayed in a youth hostel and went to the football museum and a lot of bars. It was basically a celebration of Andy's life while he was still with us and it was the most amazing time. Tom, along with four of Andy's close friends, are taking part in the Great North Run to raise money for Bowel &amp Cancer Research.  Their team name is 'The Runs' after one of the first signs of bowel cancer. The members of the team are Tom, Andy's partner of six years, Jess Lunt, 30, Elen Barfield, 30, Zoe Thirsk, 31, and Megan Key, 31. Before Andy's death, the group regularly completed challenges such as Tough Mudder, the three peaks and colour runs and thought the Great North Run would be a great next challenge. Andy had actually hoped to be there to cheer his friends along on September 9, with a few tears expected among the group as a result.  Tom said: By doing a half-marathon we want to raise as much money as possible to help people like Andy deal with the disease and prevent others having to deal with it at all. It's so important to raise awareness, it was something Andy was really passionate about and we want to continue that on. We didn’t expect him to go so soon, I thought we had more time. It will probably be a bit of an emotional finish.”

title: family horror dementia moved away
story: NewsFamily's horror as dementia sufferer, 89, is placed in bed 300 miles from homeDerek Jewson, who also has chronic heart disease, was transferred from Cornwall to Northampton - five hours awayShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAdam Aspinall21:02, 27 AUG 2018News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A dementia sufferer aged 89 has been moved 300 miles away from home for treatment because of a lack of specialist care beds.  Derek Jewson, who also has chronic heart disease, was transferred from Cornwall to Northampton. The widower’s loved ones claim he was too frail for the journey and was admitted to A&ampE shortly after arriving. Since the grandfather-of-five moved a week ago, his family have made the 600-mile, 10-hour round trip once. Mr Jewson’s son Kurt, 47, said: “Never in my wildest dreams did I think he would be moved out of Cornwall. Why was he transferred there? “He’s physically frail and was not strong enough to make the journey.”  Kurt says his father – a former politan Police motorcycle rider and lighthouse keeper from Porthleven, Cornwall – had been taken to A&ampE in Royal Cornwall Hospital in Truro before he was moved. Dad-of-two Kurt said: “He has chronic heart disease. He has water retention in his lungs and is struggling to breathe. “Why did they pressure him to travel the 300 miles within 24 hours of being in A&ampE? He needs specialist nursing care in a hospital. “He arrived in Northampton and complained of pains so was taken to A&ampE. We were told to expect the worst but he seems to have rallied.” “I have to look after the kids but he’s stuck up there in a hospital bed.  The Cornwall Partnership NHS Trust said it is “committed to providing care for people in Cornwall whenever it is safe to do so. Unfortunately, on this occasion [we] had to find a bed outside Cornwall.

title: filth vomit cigarette butts human
story: NewsInside Pontins 'holiday park from hell' - featuring filth, 'vomit', cigarette butts and 'POO on duvet'Chewing-gum was found trodden into the carpet while dirty towels and empty crates of booze were seen dumped in the entrance at the Brean Sands holiday parkShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByStephanie Balloo09:29, 26 AUG 2018Updated11:03, 26 AUG 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/stomach-churning-conditions-pontins-brean-13141233,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA-24 hour experience at Pontins turned hellish thanks to filth, 'vomit', discarded cigarette butts and overflowing rubbish. Birmingham Live reporter Stephanie Balloo decided to find out exactly what the family holiday camp is really like. During her trip, she found chewing-gum trodden into the carpet and saw dirty towels and empty crates of booze dumped in the entrance at the Brean Sands holiday park in Somerset. The choking stench of stale cigarettes filled an apartment and the toilet seat had been left broken with razor-sharp edges. It transpired a major mix up by staff meant she was given the spare key to a family's occupied flat, exposing all their belongings. One horrified dad she spoke to revealed images of what he believed to be 'human faeces' smeared on his paid-for bedding. Another told how their child had cut their feet on loose tiles in the swimming pool. Stephanie kept a detailed account of her short stay - here is her diary...  3.30pm: Popular destination with Midlands families The taxi driver tells me that Pontins Brean Sands is a popular camp with families from the Midlands. 3.55pm - Surrounded by caravan parks Driving through it seems there are plenty of other options for holidaymakers wanting to enjoy Brean Sands beach. The camp is surrounded by a number of caravan parks. I arrive at Pontins Brean Sands in a taxi and give my details to security who hand me a form to fill out. 4pm - Musty smell in chaotic arcade As I opened the door to what I imagined was a quiet reception desk, I was immediately plunged into chaos. Dozens of arcade machines all ringing simultaneously, children racing around and a musty lingering smell like an old-fashioned pub. One staff member mans the entire reception and I join the queue of around seven families - all waiting to check-in to their rooms as key collection starts from 4pm. The arcade carpet is stained with filth and blobs of chewing-gum are trodden into the disgusting flooring at reception.  4.25pm - Friendly staff The young receptionist is polite and friendly enough - calling me 'babes' and handing me a map with the route to my apartment. She also explains how I'll have to put at least &pound5 of electricity into the meter on top of the &pound139 I paid for two nights in a one-bed apartment. There is no Wifi apart from in the main building, I discover. I was directed to the fun factory to find out what entertainment the night had in store for me. Surprisingly, it seems quite an extensive list, despite previous complaints from families there is nothing for the kids. Though judging by the week's schedule, the entertainment is largely the same every night, with a Pontins character kicking off the evening, different Blue Coats performing and a disco to finish.  4.40pm - Cigarette butts and litter Walking through the holiday park to my allocated apartment I realise the reception isn't the only filthy area. Cigarette butts and rubbish is dumped all over the park - especially near the benches outside the main entrance. En route to my accommodation, I passed a neglected skate park, a strangely quiet adventure play area and a Nisa Local. The grassy areas around the play parks - dotted within the accommodation - were littered with discarded cigarettes as well.  4.45pm - 'Sick' on the steps I'm first greeted to my apartment block with the sight of what appears to be someone's vomit. I try to dodge this as I haul my suitcase up the steps. But nothing could prepare me for what I was about to experience.  4.46pm - Horrifying scenes at my apartment A full to the brim bin, burnt trodden-in popcorn and two damp towels - one strewn across the filthy corridor floor and another hung up on the rail. There was a empty crate of beer abandoned and a mug full of cigarettes and ash dumped on the floor outside too. And this was just the exterior of my allocated apartment. I was horrified but despite everything I've heard about Pontins, I thought surely this can't be right. But from the window I thought someone had genuinely left my room in this state, so I double checked the door - number 60. And double checked my documents - number 60.  4.48pm - Spare key to somebody's apartment To my surprise the key worked, but as I tried to enter, a rubbish bag full of half-eaten food and cans erupted and spilled out - blocking the entrance. A blast of stale cigarette smoke hit me and I begged internally to escape this hell. Inside, soiled underwear appeared stuck to the floor, sausages in thick grease on the oven and a bowl of what I can only describe as green slime. I spotted a mobile phone and pairs of shoes and realised Pontins staff had made a very worrying mistake.  4.54pm - Displeased neighbour The guest next door tells me the people in number 60 have been staying there for days and have just popped out for the day. It begs the question, why was the apartment all set for me to check-in? Nevertheless, the neighbour doesn’t seem surprised and tells me lots of families have had problems. They’ve lost the plot running this place, she says, as she explains how her room had no running water and a broken TV. She adds that her fire alarm keeps going off too. 5pm - Room mix-up not 'uncommon' When complaining to reception about my apartment, the formerly chirpy lady now seems inconvenienced and replies agh okay before calling the manager. She explains that there is two sets of keys and suggests the family should have checked out. What may have happened was they were meant to have booked out but obviously the system hasn't updated that they've booked an extra night or something like that. It doesn't happen too often. It's just that crossover - it has happened before though. She is unapologetic for the inconvenience caused, as is the manager - who says somebody had gone into a room they shouldn't have been in. He claims he was off to find out who they were and sort the situation. 5.10pm - New apartment damp and reeks of smoke I get my keys to the new apartment, no 61, and it is relatively clean save for the broken toilet seat with the sharp edges. The harsh smell of smoke makes me choke slightly as I enter and there's dripping damp all over the ceiling too. A bucket has been placed underneath to collect the condensation. Small yellow blobs stick to the inside of the bath, though I'm unsure what these are.  5.31pm - Faulty smoke alarms sounding The smoke alarm has randomly started ringing and refuses to stop even though there is no smoke present. There's no way to turn it off and fifteen minutes later it is still sounding. I think it is time to get out of the room. But as I leave, I realise it is the whole block and guests are furious. They say it has been going off constantly all week in the entire block every time anyone tries to cook for their children. They claim Pontins staff have not done anything to resolve the situation. 5.45pm - Furious guest says 'never again' Reacting to the fire alarm issue, a guest staying in my block says it's the first time I've ever been here and the last time too. Another guest says there was no water to bath his children and he entered the apartment to find other people's food still in the fridge. 6pm - Hidden costs Dozens of families have flocked to the fun factory as the evening entertainment kick starts with a paparazzi session with Chuckles the monkey. The bluecoats are admittedly very enthusiastic and seem to excite the children. There are huge queues of families waiting to see the favourable monkey mascot, but these extras for the kids all cost more money. It costs &pound5 for the children to have a photo with the monkey while outdated cheesy 80s music plays in the background. 6.30pm - Litter-plagued leisure area There is litter everywhere and young kids are running around without a parent nearby. Towards the rear there’s an 'inflatable zone' consisting of just two pieces of equipment, but the kids seem to be enjoying it. In the leisure zone there seems to be plenty to do, with go karting, paddle karts, a play area with swings, an 'urban gym', a skate park, trampolining and the pool. However, all of which is outdated and will cost more money in the form of tokens purchased from the leisure centre.  7pm - Pleasant beach nearby Brean Sands is just a three minute walk and is perhaps one of the few selling points for the camp. The long stretch of beach is soft and clean, perfect for young children staying in the nearby Pontins.  7.20pm - Buffet on dirty plates The evening meal at the Queen Victoria pub for those who opt for self-catering is &pound8.95 and consists of some salad, grated cheese, 'vegetable pie', cod fish cake and chips. There's also some sliced potato with 'mince-meat' underneath. Some of the plates have spots of food from previous meals clinging on and the food smells are a bit overwhelming. There's food squashed into carpet and on the floor and the dessert fridges are a mess. I force a little bit of food down but it is largely tasteless just like the squash which misleadingly brands itself as 100% juice.  7.35pm - Dirty fridges Dirty fridges full of bashed up bits of cake is the offer for dessert. Crumbs of pudding spill out from the fridges and onto the floor - ready to get squashed like everything else on the food hall floor. Though admittedly what was left of the pudding was surprisingly tasty.  8pm - Bluecoat entertainers The fun factory is packed out with hundreds of parents, young babies, toddlers and even teenagers. The blue coat entertainers are up on stage and encouraging the kids and parents alike to be silly - including dancing around like ious animals and being soaked with a water gun. Chuckles the monkey comes out on stage and pantomime style jokes are made, leaving the children in fits of giggles. Everyone seems to be having a great time - especially the children.  8.30pm - Staff selling toys During the performance, Pontins staff try to squeeze more money out of the guests by offering light up batons to the kids for a set price. There is also a shop at the front selling Pontins branded toys and another store at the side of the main hall. 9pm - Non-stop evening entertainment The entertainment is non-stop and as soon as 'party time with Chuckles' ends, the children are up on their feet once more dancing to classic school disco songs. The jam-packed line up is great to see and clearly has most people enjoying themselves. 9.15pm - Scantily-clad dancers as children watch With the children still present, the parents continue to drink and the adult entertainment begins. Female dancers in crop tops dance around the stage and sing loud rock songs in the 'I wanna rock' show. As the concert gets underway, the Blue Coats dance seductively as rows of children sit looking up at them.  9.35pm - Bouncers on patrol There are four bouncers currently manning the bar area and entrance for the fun factory. 9.45pm - Young children play while parents drink Children as young as around six play in the parks outside the apartment blocks with no parental supervision in the pitch black as adults continue to drink inside the main hall. 10.30pm - Chaos as fire alarm clears hall Families cling onto each other and ask whether they have all their belongings as they are evacuated from the building. All the while the children are screaming about their abandoned slush puppies and toys. Everyone is told to move away from the building after what seemed like a serious fire. However, it is believed a drunken guest had smashed the fire alarm.  11pm - Doors banging, kids screaming As I try to sleep, the bass from the main hall can be heard among children screaming and doors slamming shut. I've brought my own sleeping bag after hearing horror stories of blood-stained mattresses and filthy linen. Every breath I take I am inhaling more and more of the lingering second-hand smoke which clings to the walls, furniture and very atmosphere of the musty apartment. 3am - Parents squabbling with children I was awoken to the sound of what I thought was a fight kicking off outside my apartment. As I looked out into the corridor, parents were arguing loudly with their children in the doorway to their room. The row lasted around an hour before they eventually returned to their rooms. 4.10am - Screaming girl The sleepless night in hell continues as I'm woken by the short sharp scream of a young girl. It seems to have come from near the squabbling, restless family - who to my annoyance refuse to sleep. 8.45am - Average breakfast The Queen Victoria is fairly quiet and there seems to be no staff in sight. It is a buffet again, which is all the camp offers in terms of cooked food. Segments of oranges, a fruit cocktail, toast, cereal or the main fry up in silver trays are the options available. But the sausages are spotted with transparent blobs of fat which are chewy to eat. Nothing tastes fresh, and it is fairly average.  10.15am - Huge queues for swimming pool Around 50 families are queuing for the swimming pool and have been for more than an hour with their children in just swimwear and a towel. One frustrated child - who clearly doesn't understand time yet - says why are they not open yet, it's stupid. The families are forced to wait a total of an hour and a half to be let into the swimming pool for their turn. The long wait was due to no lifeguards being present at the pool. 10.30am - Rammed pool The pool is rammed full of parents and children - each with around two square metres to swim and play and yet more are piling in. It has a capacity of 120 people, which is far too many for the size of the pool, in my opinion. The much-anticipated Flume feature of the pool is out of action due to a technical fault.  11.30am - Child cuts foot on broken pool tile A young child is hopping around in her swimming costume and towel with toilet paper wrapped round a bloody foot. Her father claims she had cut her foot on a broken, loose tile at the bottom of the pool. In images it appears many of the tiles on the bottom of the pool are either dirty or missing.  11.45am - 'Faeces' smothered on duvet I speak to another unhappy guest who is disgusted by his experience at Pontins. He shows me images of what he claims are human faeces on a duvet supplied by Pontins for a sum of &pound8. Their mattress, he reports, also had smears of poo all over it. The family, who have come from Cardiff, claim they waited from 4pm until 11pm at night for clean bed linen for their children to finally go to sleep in. He says 99.9 per cent of people are unhappy here and have complained too.  12pm - Claims of mice and second pool injury Another family, living at the other side of the park in the chalets, claim mice have chewed through the furniture in their room. While a third family say their child lifted one of the loose tiles above his head in the swimming pool after cutting his foot on it. 1pm - Haven is the Ritz compared to this A pair of unhappy mums - who brought their kids down together - explain how they had bought bleach to clean their chalet themselves. We got bleach flash, wipes, everything to clean as the smell was like rot, damp, festering bodies. We had a conversation last night saying overall there's plenty for the children to do, entertainment's fine, but the smell of cigarettes was disgusting. We've stayed in a lot of holiday parks, Butlins, Haven and this is the worst. Haven is like the Ritz compared to this. 2pm - Same activities, different day On the surface, there seems to be plenty of activities for the children and the whole family in the day time including Curling, Cine Racing, a Disco Bingo and photo opportunities with Pontins characters. However, when dissected this is nearly exactly the same as yesterday's daytime entertainment. And most of which needs to be paid for on-top of the accommodation price. When speaking with families at the end of my stay, many say there is not much to do for the kids in the day - and every day is the same.

title: former tesco worker reveals top
story: NewsFormer Tesco worker reveals the top 10 things that irritate staff members more than anythingHere's our top tips on how you can avoid an annoyed glance from a staff member the next time you go shoppingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura Forsyth20:49, 27 AUG 2018Updated21:30, 27 AUG 2018NewsA former Tesco staff member reveals the top things that tick off staff members "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLike any other job, being employed by a supermarket carries with it its own set of individual quirks. But have you ever wondered about the behaviours which tick off supermarket staff? One woman, who used to work for supermarket giant Tesco , has revealed her biggest work-related bug bears. title: fully clothed woman walks sea
story: News'Fully-clothed' woman walks into the sea 'after phone call' at exclusive Sandbanks resort leading to dramatic rescueEyewitnesses say the 'fully-clothed' woman walked into the sea after finishing a phone conversation on the seafront in Dorset - she was brought out an hour laterShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAlex Shipman15:07, 27 AUG 2018Updated15:14, 27 AUG 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/dramatic-moment-sandbanks-police-raced-13146825,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the dramatic moment cops stripped off and waded into the sea to save a woman who 'disappeared into the water' at Britain's most exclusive beach.  The brave police officers were seen quickly moving through the ocean in a bid to rescue the 'fully-clothed' woman at Sandbanks, Dorset, on Saturday evening.  Eyewitnesses say the mystery female ended up three quarters of a mile - nearly 4,000 feet - out to sea after finishing a phone conversation on the seafront. She apparently walked into the water at around 7.30pm, as the sun was setting. She was brought out an hour later.  Footage shows eight police officers looking out to sea, into the distance, before two remove some of their clothes and wade into the water after the woman. The incident disrupted a wedding party photoshoot at Sandbanks, which is a haven for celebrities and has been dubbed a 'millionaires' playground'. Eyewitness Peter Hirst, 54, claimed the woman had been drinking alcohol before she walked into the sea with her clothes on and 'disappeared'. He said: “The woman was on the telephone and drinking alcohol.  “When the conversation ended she got up and walked into the sea fully-clothed - it’s shallow for a while and you could see her disappearing into the night. “She was about three quarters of a mile away when the policemen entered the water. He added: A couple had just got married and were having pictures taken on the beach at the time. title: how double your holiday 2018
story: NewsHow to double your holiday in 2018 - get 24 days off in a row using just 14 days annual leaveAll it takes a little strategic planning and you can double your days off - there's still time top sneak some extra days inShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJo-Anne RowneyAudience Growth EditorRachael Burford15:00, 27 AUG 2018Updated15:14, 27 AUG 2018NewsYou can more than double your holiday time next year "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf someone said to you you're able to double your holiday days off, you'd probably laugh at them, but it's actually possible. Most workers in Britain are entitled to about 28 days of leave a year.  But, with some strategic planning you could beat the system and more than double your holiday time in 2018.  Anyone who wants about two months away from the office, while only taking the allocated holiday could have done so - with some careful planning.  The system works by calculating days away from work around bank holidays and weekends, according to Instant Offices .  So here is how to make sure you get the maximum benefit when booking annual leave.  Note: This only works if you work a normal shift pattern with weekends and Bank Holidays off. Sorry everyone else. Here's what to do  Christmas Day fell on a Monday last year, so if you were a clever planner you'd have booked off from December 23 to January 1 you'd get a 10-day holiday for the price of just three days.  If you missed your chance, don't worry.  Over the Easter break you needed to ask your boss for March 24 to April 8 off work. That's a 16 day break but only uses eight days of holiday.  The extra days come from the bank holidays - Good Friday , Easter Monday  and the early May holiday  - plus the three weekends the period covers.  Alternatively you could have taken off the 24 days from May 5 to May 28 by using up just 14 days of leave because of the May Day and Spring bank holiday.   Missed those? Well this weekend you had another chance.  You could have a 9-day break from August 25 to September 9 by using just four days of leave.  Christmas is coming The final way to work to system in your favour comes at Christmas.  By using up just seven days of paid leave, workers can take off from December 24 and not have to return to work until January 6 , 2018 - a 16 day break.     If you're interested in how it all works, take a look at the instantoffices chart.

title: how man went super fit
story: NewsHow dad-of-two went from a super-fit marathon runner to weighing 37 STONEDetermined Chris Larkin, 63, plans to run The Great Welsh Marathon after embarking on a major health mission and losing nine stoneShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByLaura ClementsHana Carter11:02, 27 AUG 2018Updated13:10, 27 AUG 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/man-went-super-fit-marathon-13146256,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn ex-marathon runner who ballooned to 37 stone has vowed to get his trainers back on 40 years after his first race. Chris Larkin, 63, was just 23 when he ran his first marathon in 1982 - when he weighed a healthy 13 stone. But after falling into a routine of fast food dinners and little exercise, Chris piled on the pounds and at his heaviest he tipped the scales at just under 40 stone. Now the dad-of-two has embarked on a weight loss mission and shed a whopping nine stone. And he plans to run The Great Welsh marathon in 2022.  Speaking to WalesOnline, he said: It creeps up on you. By the mid-90s, I was getting heavier and heavier. I was working as a sales rep and basically eating out of a petrol station all the time. I just didn't make time to eat properly. The scary thing is you can easily put on a pound over a month without really noticing. But a pound a month is a stone every year.  By 2006 he had reached more than 30 on the scales.  His daily routine involved little exercise and he spent most of his time behind a desk.  He rendered himself practically bed bound, saying that he was too big to get off the sofa. He said: I reached my heaviest weight in June 2016 - 37 stone. At that weight I thought my life was over, it was awful.  His weight loss started after one of his colleagues bet him &pound100 that he could not lose three stone in three months. He tripled the weight loss expected of him, losing nine stone in a year. Chris now is taking part in a swimming challenge for Running Down for Dementia as he is unable to run due to a knee injury. He aims to swim 130km for the charity, after he lost both of his parents to the illness. Chris met his wife, Karen, online. She has endlessly supported his transformation and has lost 4 stone herself in the process.

title: man eats nothing chicken nuggets
story: NewsMan ate almost nothing but chicken nuggets and chips for 20 years due to eating disorderRyan Howarth, 21, struggled to consume anything other than the low-nutrition classic childhood meal from the age of four and felt like eating much more would be like eating insectsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicolas Fernandes17:43, 27 AUG 2018Updated17:54, 27 AUG 2018NewsRyan Howarth with his chicken nuggets and chips "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who ate chicken nuggets and chips almost every day for nearly two decades suddenly changed his diet in just minutes. Ryan Howarth struggled to consume anything other than the low-nutrition meal from the age of four and felt like eating much more would be like eating insects. The 21-year-old, from Andover, Hampshire, has Selective Eating Disorder, which left him eating chicken nuggets and chips for 90% of the last 17 years - occasionally being able to eat steak, sausage, pasta and sweets. When offered other foods, the cinema host felt like they were so foreign that they were impossible for him to taste. He even cried for 20 minutes when his mum asked him to try root vegetable mash.  The disorder saw him eat by himself, leave the room when everyone else was eating and have arguments with his parents His family kept reminding him about the health risks of his diet, which led him to finding a therapist who persuaded him to try out some other foods before even leaving the room. Within minutes, Ryan was eating a iety of dishes with no hesitation. He said: I used to just think that's what my life was. I just ate the foods I wanted to. The way I reacted when someone asked me to eat more was the same way most people would react if I asked them to eat an exotic food, like insects. It just felt so foreign to me. My family started getting worried that my diet could cause health problems later on in life.  When I was still in the room with Felix, I was eating a bunch of different foods without hesitation. Now I'm eating so many different things. There's ones I like and there's ones I don't like, but I'm basically testing everything out. It's amazing how I'm enjoying foods I never expected I'd like. I never thought I'd like pineapple, but now it's one of my favorites. Just one month after he's been introducing these foods to his diet, Ryan already feels healthier. Before the switch, he had a low energy levels, took a lot of vitamins to make up for the nutrients he wasn't getting from his meals and ate a chocolate bar whenever he was feeling weak. Ryan said: It's amazing. I feel healthier and I feel like I have more energy throughout the day.  That was no way to live. I was eating candy to keep myself going. I had three cavities as a kid. Another thing Ryan realized after changing his diet was that his eating disorder had a negative affect on his relationship with his family saying he alienated himself from everyone and dreaded going out to restaurants. Ryan said: I never used to eat with my family. I feel like I was letting them down and I was also letting myself down. Now I finally know what it's like to sit and have a meal with my family. It's really nice. I always tried to avoid going to restaurants or only went to ones where I could order the few foods I liked. Now I can finally go out to eat with my family and have lots of different foods to chose from. His mum Christiane, 45, has noticed a drastic change in his personality since taking up the new diet.

title: mum becomes one uks youngest
story: NewsMum diagnosed as one of the UK's youngest dementia patients aged just 31 after getting lost on way homeRachel Potter, from Chesterfield, is now unable to walk and write unassisted, her distraught family sayShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJames Somper13:38, 27 AUG 2018Updated13:51, 27 AUG 2018NewsRachel Potter, pictured with her daughter Brooke, was just 31 when she learned she had dementia "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum from Chesterfield is believed to be one of the youngest people in Britain to be diagnosed with dementia - at the age of just 31. Rachel Potter was diagnosed after getting lost while driving home from her dad's home, prompting relatives to urge her to see doctors. Now her distraught family say she is far from the woman they once knew - as she is unable to write or walk without help. Mum-of-one Rachel, now 33, received the devastating news in 2016. Her devastated dad, Kev Potter, 61, said that his daughter isn't the same person as she used to be - with the young woman now requiring visits from carers twice a day.  And he said the condition is affecting her relationship with daughter Brooke. Kev said: Being able to walk any distance now is quite for painful for her and her handwriting has been reduced to a child's scrawl. Doctors have told Kev that they believe Rachel to be one of the youngest people in the UK to have dementia. Her condition - Gerstmann-Str ussler-Scheinker syndrome - is a degenerative condition that affects the nervous system and gradually inhibits coordination, speech and muscle control. Former UK Border Force official Kev said: It's absolutely heartbreaking - we were absolutely devastated when we found out.  We can see the change in her. She's not the same person she was, she was a bubbling, outgoing girl with a massive circle of friends who loved working and socialising. She travelled all over the world. Now, she can't work or drive anymore. She's deteriorated rapidly, her mobility is decreasing all the time as well as her cognitive skills. She can't write properly anymore or cook. She has trouble with directions and finding her way. As time goes on her relationship with Brooke will be affected as the condition gets worse. Her world now is a few close friends, her family and her carers. The syndrome is a degenerative condition that affects the nervous system. Both Rachel's mum - who is divorced from Kev - as well as Rachel's granddad have had the condition.  Rachel's mum, June, requires round-the-clock care and Rachel's grandad died after battling the condition for six months. Now Kev is concerned Brooke too could inherit the syndrome - but she may choose to never find out, Kev said: There's a chance Brooke could have the gene too. She won't know until she's 18 and that's if she decides to have the test. It's a ticking time bomb in our family. Kev said Rachel's condition has created enormous pain in their family. Relatives first became concerned after she became lost while driving home from a visit to her father and stepmother. Eventually, Rachel phoned her worried dad in a state of panic, not knowing where she was. Kev said: We phoned her for hours and she didn't pick up.  Eventually she picked up and said she was in a pub in Wakefield. She was very upset and said she hadn't been able to read the signs on the motorway or follow the directions on the satnav and she didn't know where she was. From that point, we got in touch with a GP. It was only after the GP referred Rachel to a doctor at Sheffiled Hospital and then University College Hospital in London that Rachel's family were given the terrible news that she had Gerstmann-Str ussler-Scheinker syndrome. Now, the mum-of-one requires help getting in and out of the bath as well as cooking in addition to doctor's visiting her every six to eight weeks to do a series of cognitive tests. But despite the care and support she receives, Kev said that Rachel's condition is totally unpredictable. Kev said: Rachel's doctors compare her test results to previous tests to see if she's got any worse. They've been brilliant. The condition is so fluid, it's like a wave. We have good days and bad days. We took her on a holiday recently and Rachel said she was walking to a shop which we could see directly in front of where we were staying. Half-an-hour went by and we didn't see her. We were starting to get worried so I ended up calling security who eventually found her after two hours. She was very upset. Rachel walked past the caravan after getting lost. There have been a few other instances when I've taken her out and parked close by to wherever we're going and she's come out, looked at the car with me sat in it and walked away, completely lost. She's started shuffling quite a bit so it's becoming more difficult for her to walk.

title: uk weather forecast el nino
story: NewsUK weather forecast: El Nino to bring Indian summer with Met Office predicting MONTHS of hotter conditionsForecasters predict the balmy temperatures experienced in the UK throughout summer could make a welcome return - after a washout bank holiday SundayShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAlistair GrantAbigail O'Leary12:36, 27 AUG 2018Updated13:03, 27 AUG 2018NewsBeach-goers relax outside huts on Barry Island, in the Vale of Glamorgan, Wales "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBritain is set to enjoy highs of 30C as an Indian Summer sweeps across the country, with Met Office forecasts backing hotter conditions until autumn. Forecasters predict the balmy temperatures experienced in the UK throughout summer could make a welcome return - after a washout bank holiday Sunday. According to the The Weather Outlook, the mercury could hit 30C in some parts, while the Met Office said a “very warm” September is on the cards. El Nino - the warming of eastern Pacific sea-surface temperatures – is predicted to bring about a return of the hot weather.  The phenomenon boosts autumn temperatures in western Europe, according to a Met Office El Nino impacts map showed. The Met Office said: “Heat released by El Nino events typically drives a short-lived spike in global temperatures. “A region marked ‘warmer likely’ in El Nino conditions means a greater than 50 per cent chance that the temperature will be in the top third of temperatures observed in the season.” Met Office forecaster Emma Smith said: “Wednesday’s cold front sees rain break up as it moves south, but high pressure from Thursday sees most places dry with sunny spells. “We could see 24C by Friday and up to 26C as autumn starts on Saturday. That’s warm for the time of year, as average highs are only 21C.    “The pattern will continue, and temperatures could be into the low or mid-20s in spells until mid or late September, which is warm or very warm for the year. “The warmest and driest weather will be in the South and East, with the North and West seeing outbreaks of rain at times, but having bright spells also. “Bank Holiday Monday’s sunny spells up to 22C were a lot better than a wet and windy Sunday. “But temperatures are lower than previously so that impacts summer’s average temperature. We’ll have to wait and see where summer ends up in the rankings.” The Met Office long-range forecast leading into October also suggested temperatures would be higher than normal.

story: NewsWhat Meghan Markle arranged for best pal's 'stagette' as her maid-of-honour - and it included sunbathing and shotsMeghan Markle's best pal Lindsay Roth asked her to be her maid-of-honour- but there was one thing she was very nervous aboutShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor14:09, 27 AUG 2018NewsMeghan Markle's best pal Lindsay Roth tied the knot in 2016 "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Before she said her own wedding vows and married her prince, Meghan Markle stood beside her best pal on her special day as maid-of-honour. title: david katz know far after
story: NewsDavid Katz: All we know so far after Jacksonville shooter "snapped" during video game tournament killing twoWARNING - DISTRESSING VIDEO: Everything we know about Katz, who has been compared to school shooter Adam LanzaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByChris kitching13:44, 27 AUG 2018Updated14:00, 27 AUG 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/us-news/video/professional-player-shot-during-live-13144234,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailDavid Katz has been named as the disgruntled gunman who killed two people and wounded nine others in the latest mass shooting in America. The 24-year-old, wearing an army green jacket, killed himself after shooting rival gamers at a Madden NFL 19 video game tournament in Jacksonville, Florida on Sunday afternoon. Eyewitnesses say Katz was angry and snapped after losing an intense game and being eliminated from the competition. He was seeking revenge when he returned about 15-20 minutes later with a handgun. They said Katz - who has been compared to Sandy Hook school shooter Adam Lanza - had been acting weird, wore the same clothes on both days of the eSports event, and refused to shake hands and stared blankly after losing a game on Saturday. Who was David Katz?  Katz, 24, was from Baltimore, Maryland, about 750 miles north of Jacksonville. He was an avid video gamer and was well-known on the pro Madden circuit under nicknames or handles including Bread, mrslicedbread, ravens2012champs and ravenschamp, the latter two being references to the Baltimore Ravens of the National Football League . But fellow gamers have said they noticed strange behaviour from him, including a lack of emotion and blank stares. In 2014, court records from his parents' divorce said he had significant medical problems and healthcare needs. At the time, his dad worked for Nasa and his mum worked for the US Food and Drug Administration, WBAL TV reported. In February 2017 Katz won a Madden 17 championship hosted by the NFL's Buffalo Bills - a tournament that included one of his victims, Elijah Clayton.  Katz was given a cheque for 10,000  and a Bills jersey with the name Madden Champ and number 17. An announcer said during one of the games: “You are not gonna see much emotion from our guy Bread. David Katz keeps to himself. He’s a man of business. He’s not here to make friends. To even get him to open up to talk to you about anything, it’s like pulling teeth, man. After winning the Buffalo event, Katz told ex-Bills player Steve Tasker in an interview: I think personally I'm one of the better players. But fellow gamers had accused him of cheating and making online head-to-head games glitchy to gain an advantage. The FBI, ATF and police have been searching Katz's father's upscale Baltimore townhouse, and police in Jacksonville have located and seized his car. It is believed he had been staying at a hotel nearby. What happened?  At least a dozen shots rang out at the GLHF Gaming Bar at Chicago Pizza, which was hosting the tournament, at about 1.30pm on Sunday. Terrifying footage from a live stream on the website Twitch shows two young men playing against each other when the shooting starts. A red laser dot - believed to be a laser sight from Katz's semi-automatic handgun - suddenly appears on victim Elijah Clayton's chest as shots are fired. People begin screaming and a man says: Oh f***, what did he shoot me with? At least a dozen shots are heard as terrified gamers ran for their lives or hid amid the chaos.  At some point, Katz fatally shot himself inside the shopping centre as police raced to the scene. His body was found near the bodies of the two who were shot dead. In the aftermath, there is panic and confusion. A man appears to be in shock, repeatedly saying Oh my God, while another man tells a victim to sit down and asks: Where did you get hit? Eyewitnesses said families with babies were inside the venue at the Jacksonville Landing, a downtown marketplace on the St Johns River. Raheem Johnson, a cook at Chicago Pizza, told of the chilling moment he saw the gunman. Mr Johnson told CBS News that he grabbed two kitchen knives in case he had to defend himself, adding: Dude came in there to kill. It was rampage mode. Why did Katz target the tournament?  Eyewitnesses said Katz was angry after losing again on Sunday and being eliminated from the tournament. Fellow gamer Steven Jauski, who ran and hid in a toilet when gunfire erupted, told the Los Angeles Times that the gunman came back and “targeted a few people” before killing himself. Eyewitnesses Rico Martinez and Jais Long told the Tampa Bay Times that the gunman was nerdy and got mad because he lost. He went to his car, got a gun and came back inside and started blasting everybody, the pair said. Marquis Williams told the Tampa Bay Times that Katz was wearing an army green jacket when he shot up the venue. His girlfriend, Taylor Poindexter, said the couple watched the shooter take aim at his victims.  She said: We did see him, two hands on the gun, walking back, just popping rounds. I was scared for my life and my boyfriend's. A Chicago Pizza worker named Brianna told ABC News that Katz had argued with another gamer and gone to the back of the room, where he waited for a few minutes, before opening fire. Toshiba Sharon, a commentator on the tournament's live stream, was just a few feet away from Katz when the shooting began. Mr Sharon told reporters that the gunman was eliminated from the event and came back with a gun about 15-20 minutes later. Mr Sharon, who survived by hiding under a table, said Katz shot Mr Clayton first and then continued on firing. Police have declined to comment on the reason for the shooting. Detectives have obtained a video of the incident. Gunman was acting weird, wearing same clothes  Dennis Alston told Action News Jax that he and another gamer who beat Katz during the tournament are both still alive. He said: I felt like he was targeting, but I don't think it was the people who beat him. It seemed like it was premeditated. Mr Alston said Katz was wearing sunglasses and had been weird all weekend. He added: He didn't speak to anybody, even after we played, I beat him , I went to shake his hand and tell him good game and he just looked at me. He didn't say anything. He had on basically the same outfit that he had on the day before. Police said Katz used one gun during his rampage. It was unclear how he had obtained the weapon. Why is he being compared to Adam Lanza?  After Sunday's shooting, social media users drew comparisons between Katz and Adam Lanza, who killed 26 people, including 20 children, at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Connecticut in December 2012. Lanza, a bullied loner who was mentally ill, shot and killed his mum Nancy before the massacre, and took his own life as emergency services responded to the mass shooting. Comparisons between Katz and other mass shooters were made as a profile and photos of the gunman emerged on Sunday. One Twitter user wrote: David Katz, Nicholas Cruz, James Holmes, and Adam Lanza all mass shooters, and have that scary hollow look in their eyes. Another added: David Katz — shooter in the Jacksonville Shooting — eerily looks a lot like Lanza the guy that did Sandy Hook. Who were the victims?  Two young men were killed and nine other people were injured by gunfire in Jacksonville. At least two people were hurt when they were trampled as gamers and spectators fled in terror. The two men who were shot dead have been named by friends as Elijah  Clayton, 22, and Taylor Robertson, 27. Mr Clayton, of Woodland Hills, California, was known by his Madden names True or Trueboy, and had reportedly won more than 50,000  in prize money. An EA Sports profile reads: Despite a rough season, True remains one of the best around and can potentially win it all when it's done. Mr Clayton was shot dead as he played against Wesley “Joe Rice” Gittens, who survived the incident.

story: NewsAsylum seekers' boat runs aground in crocodile-infested Australian waters leaving dozens missingThe Vietnamese boat is the first asylum seeker vessel to come ashore in four yearsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAmy Coles16:41, 27 AUG 2018Updated17:05, 27 AUG 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/world-news/video/boat-asylum-seekers-runs-aground-13147540,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA boat full of asylum seekers went aground in crocodile-infested waters in Australia and on the edge of a dangerous rainforest. The Vietnamese vessel is the first to reach the Australian coast in almost four years. Locals raised the alarm when they saw a large group of people fleeing the crippled vessel at Cape Kimberley near the mouth of the Daintree River and make a risky swim to a beach. Some vanished into a nearby mangrove rainforest at the northern end of the Queensland state.  Inside they will face crocodiles, snakes, and giant cassowaries - one of the world's deadliest birds. According to local media, 15 people have been traced so far but two others, including the boat's captain are still missing. Although, according to the Brisbane Courier up to 20 remain unfound after the boat sunk today. State emergency service area controller Peter Rinaudo told ABC: I hope the people, however many there are, get located - it's not a nice area for them to be in. Australia is known for its tough immigration policy. In recent years the country has attracted criticism for the conditions at its immigration camps on a series of remote Pacific islands. Currently Australia has one such centre on the Pacific island nation of Nauru and another on Manus Island in Papua New Guinea.

title: brave girl 9 who once
story: NewsBrave girl, 9, who once tried to pinch Kate Middleton's flowers dies "beautiful" death in her parents' armsLittle Mia Murchison died 10 days ago after courageously battling a rare, genetic disease that robbed her of the ability to walk, talk, see or eatShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans11:19, 27 AUG 2018Updated16:38, 27 AUG 2018NewsBrave Mia Murchison gave her last little breath on August 17 "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave nine-year-old girl who once tried to pinch Kate Middleton's flowers has died a beautiful death in her parents' arms just four years on. Mia Murchison gave her last little breath on August 17 after battling a rare, genetic disease that robbed her of the ability to walk, talk, see or eat. She was laid to rest last week by her heartbroken parents, who drove her casket to her funeral themselves in their 'final family adventure' with her. Mum Peta said it was the saddest and most beautiful day. Mia, who had been diagnosed with Batten disease at the age of three, was a very happy and affectionate little girl who loved to laugh and smile. In April 2014, she was pictured donning a stunning 'princess dress' as she met the Duchess of Cambridge at a children's hospice in eastern Australia.      Then only four, the youngster 'tried to steal' flowers Kate had been given as she sat beside her mum at Bear Cottage in the Sydney suburb of Manly. In response, the beaming Duchess, who had kindly crouched down beside Mia and Peta, said she could have them. They then all had a giggle together. Kate, who was visiting the hospice with husband Prince William as part of their Australian tour, is said to have listened so attentively to the family. When Mia said the word baby to her, she replied: Yes, I have a baby, baby George, according to a post on the Murchisons' Bounce4Batten website . She also joined in singing as the little girl's younger brother, Toby, took centre stage and performed 'Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star' for her. The tot was said to be very excited to perform for a real Princess.  Meanwhile, Mia's dad, Hamish, was startled when William approached him in the hospice's garden and remarked: You must be Hamish, Mia’s father? The engaging prince also complimented Mia on her gorgeous dress. The family had their pictures taken with the royal couple by award-winning photographer Marieke Jongerius, who has volunteered for Bear Cottage. They were left with very special memories from the day. Mia, who was born in Dublin, Ireland, suffered from CLN2 disease, one of a group of disorders which are collectively known as Batten disease. As well as losing her ability to walk or talk, she had to be fed through a tube. Her family, who relocated from Ireland to Singapore and now live in New South Wales, have been dedicated to raising awareness of the condition.      They have set up the Facebook page Bounce4Batten , where they announced the heartbreaking news 10 days ago that their beloved Mia had passed away. A post on the page at the time read: Mia died this morning at home in our arms. So incredibly sad and beautiful. So very loved and adored. A later post, by Peta, revealed her bright shining star had been laid to rest. She said: Yesterday was the saddest and most beautiful day for our family. Mia’s casket had a simple wooden name plate that we will keep forever. I never thought you could like a casket but hers was so beautiful covered in flowers and so very Mia. I loved it. It was very special Hamish driving Mia to her funeral himself in his car with Toby and I - our final family adventure together with Mia. She added: I was never going to ready for this goodbye but it was heavenly and more beautiful than I ever could have imagined. So raw and honest. Our family all coming together to cry, laugh, sob and honour our little girl.  The most ethereal of flowers  are in Mia’s room. Pink ribbons and drawings by her friends pinned to her wall. It feels like we are being lifted up with all love pouring in to our little family. I can’t believe we made it through yesterday but we did and now we are looking forward to celebrating Mia’s life next Tuesday 28th August. Mia, who had been a healthy, robust baby who met all of her development milestones with ease, first had a seizure in August 2012 aged three. Before this, any slight behaviour changes or concerns had been explained by the 'terrible twos' and other factors such as the move to Singapore. But a month after the seizure, she suffered a second. Following ious tests, the little girl was diagnosed with idiopathic photosensitive epilepsy. However, her condition continued to deteriorate, as she suffered more seizures as well as language and memory problems. She also began to fall frequently and lost the confidence to walk down steps or run, her family say.  It was in May 2013, nine months after her first seizure, that she was diagnosed with Batten disease, which would go on to claim her life. She and her loved ones relocated to Australia to be closer to their relatives. And there, beautiful Mia marked her ninth birthday last month. She passed away only weeks later. Although it was short, the youngster's life was exceptional. She showed incredible strength, joyfulness and love to those around her. Her relatives are now fundraising in her memory. The money raised will go to charities chosen by Peta and Hamish - including Bear Cottage, where Mia and Toby used to happily play instruments, spend time with other children and make the most of the sun-soaked garden. A dedicated GoFundMe page reads: The love that Mia gave &amp the joyfulness that everyone experienced through Mia’s life is her gift to us all. However in the six years since Mia’s diagnosis there have been countless supporters, champions, advocates, friends and professionals who have extended themselves for Mia and our family. We would like to recognize and support the organisations that supported Mia’s joyful life. It adds: On 17 August 2018, Mia gave us her last little breath.

title: tourists told stay out water
story: NewsTourists told to stay out of water at French beach after warning over frisky dolphinThe sexually frustrated bottlenose - called Zafar - has been scaring tourists and locals by approaching them and trying to rub up against themShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRachel Bishop16:28, 27 AUG 2018Updated16:50, 27 AUG 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/weird-news/video/tourists-told-stay-out-water-13147810,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA seaside village in France has banned people from swimming in the sea because of an overly amorous dolphin. The sexually frustrated bottlenose has been scaring tourists and locals by approaching them and trying to rub up against them. The 10ft-long male, nicknamed Zafar, had been hanging around the the harbour in the Breton city of Brest for months - delighting tourists and locals. Children in sailing schools were delighted when the dolphin would suddenly turn up and frolic around their boats, and Zafar sometimes let swimmers grip onto his dorsal fin and go for a ride with him.  But then a few weeks ago he changed as he moved south to the village of Land&eacutevennec. While locals say Zafar hasn't been aggressive officials fear he is now getting too close to boats and swimmers alike, even in shallow waters, reports Le Telegramme. Last month a swimmer reportedly had to be rescued by a boat when the dolphin stopped her returning to the shore. But the final last straw appeared to come last week when the dolphin tossed a young woman bather in the air with its nose.

title: blether former celtic player was in the only dundee team to win trophy
story: My old buddy Frankie Campbell got back in touch.Frankie and I grew up together in Balerno Street in Douglas, Dundee, and spent many an evening kicking a football around the concrete street.Frankie was a very skilled player and had a spell with Celtic.I’ve told in previous BwB articles how one of his team-mates among the Parkhead youth players was Kenny Dalglish, and they used to hang out after training.Prior to all that, Frankie was part of the great 1968 Lawside Academy U/15 football team which won the Scottish Cup – the Intermediate Shield to give it it’s ‘posh’ name.And that great feat was the reason he contacted me.Said Frankie: “I had to send you this picture. 50 years after the event, we had a mini reunion of the old Lawside Academy Scottish Cup-winning team. Mike Kolacz organised the reunion, and we remain the only Dundee team to win the trophy.“In the first leg of the final against Hillhead High School at Tannadice Park, Davy Henderson scored four goals in seven minutes to turn a 2-2 half-time score in a 6-2 victory.“The second leg to place at Motherwell FC’s Fir Park.“Davy had an ‘off day’ and scored only two in a 3-1 victory for a 9-3 aggregate win.“The manager and tactical genius of the team was Joe Hart.“I’d like to thank Mikey for organising the get-together.”The Lawside team for both legs of the final was Joe Forbes Frankie Campbell, Mike Kolacz Derek Mousely  Gerry Toshney , Larry Blyth Davy Henderson, Davy Brogan, George Forbes, Joe Tront , Davy Alexander.The photo shows  Davy Alexander, Joe Hart, Mike Kolacz, Frankie Campbell and Davy Henderson.
